The unresolved hard X-ray background: the missing source population
implied by the Chandra and XMM–Newton deep fields
M. A. Worsley,1 A. C. Fabian,1 F. E. Bauer,1 D. M. Alexander,1 G. Hasinger,2
S. Mateos,3 H. Brunner,2 W. N. Brandt4 and D. P. Schneider4
1Institute of Astronomy, Madingley Road, Cambridge CB3 0HA
2Max-Planck-Institut fu¨r extraterrestrische Physik, Postfach 1319, D-85740 Garching, Germany
3Instituto de Fı´sica de Cantabria (CSIC-UC), 39005 Santander, Spain
4Department of Astronomy and Astrophysics, 525 Davey Laboratory, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, USA
Accepted 2004 December 9. Received 2004 December 8; in original form 2004 September 30
ABSTRACT
We extend our earlier work on X-ray source stacking in the deep XMM–Newton observation of
the Lockman Hole, to the 2-Ms Chandra Deep Field North (CDF-N) and the 1-Ms Chandra
Deep Field South (CDF-S). The XMM–Newton work showed the resolved fraction of the X-ray
background (XRB) to be ∼80–100 per cent at 2 keV but this decreased to only ∼50 per cent
above ∼8 keV. The CDF-N and CDF-S probe deeper, and are able to fill in some of the missing
fraction in the 4–6 keV range, but the resolved fraction in the 6–8 keV band remains only
∼60 per cent, confirming the trend seen with XMM–Newton. The missing XRB component
has a spectral shape that is consistent with a population of highly obscured active galactic nuclei
(AGN) at redshifts ∼0.5–1.5 and with absorption column densities of ∼1023–1024 cm−2.
Key words: surveys – galaxies: active – diffuse radiation – X-rays: diffuse background –
X-rays: galaxies.
1 I N T RO D U C T I O N
The nature of the X-ray background (XRB) has been a subject of
contention since its discovery 40 years ago (Giacconi et al. 1962).
It is now clear that that at energies above ∼1 keV the background
is made up of the summed emission from point sources, princi-
pally active galactic nuclei (AGN). The spectrum measured by the
HEAO satellite (Marshall et al. 1980) is similar in shape to 40 keV
bremsstrahlung and is well described by a  = 1.4 power law from
∼1 up to ∼15 keV, where it starts to flatten off before peaking in
νI ν at ∼30 keV. Below ∼1 keV the background is dominated by
diffuse Galactic and local bubble emission; the purely extragalactic
component has not been well determined.
Resolving the XRB into discrete sources is crucial to understand-
ing the nature of the AGN and galaxy populations in the Universe.
It also allows us to place limits on the residual XRB emission
which can be attributed to other processes, including that from
truly diffuse extragalactic emission. A significant amount (∼70–
80 per cent) of the 0.5–2 keV XRB was resolved into point sources
by ROSAT (Hasinger et al. 1998), but progress at harder energies
has required the improved sensitivity and spatial resolution of the
Chandra and XMM–Newton observatories. XMM–Newton was able
E-mail: maw@ast.cam.ac.uk
to resolve some ∼60 per cent of the 5–10 keV background in a
deep survey of the Lockman Hole, reaching a limiting flux of ∼3 ×
10−15 erg cm−2s−1 in this band (Hasinger et al. 2001). The Chandra
Deep Field North (CDF-N) and Chandra Deep Field South (CDF-S)
probe down to ∼1.4–2.8 × 10−16 erg cm−2s−1 (over 2–8 keV) and
resolve ∼70–90 per cent of the background in this broad, hard band
(Giacconi et al. 2002; Moretti et al. 2002; Alexander et al. 2003;
and references therein).
The large resolved fractions found in the deep surveys appear
to solve the problem of the origin of the XRB in terms of known
sources; an extrapolation of the 0.5–2 keV band log N–log S dis-
tribution points to an integrated flux consistent with the full XRB
level. The substantial resolved fraction in the broad 2–10 keV band
is not entirely consistent with this picture; a similar extrapolation
of the 2–10 keV log N–log S distribution is, at most, only able to ac-
count for some 93 per cent of the total XRB and is only marginally
consistent with complete resolution (Moretti et al. 2003). The most
recent XRB intensity measurement by De Luca & Molendi (2004)
would make the fraction only ∼80 per cent.
To investigate in detail the resolved XRB fraction as a function of
energy, Worsley et al. (2004) carried out a source-stacking analysis
of ∼700 ks of accumulated XMM–Newton exposure in the Lock-
man Hole. Source photometry was used to determine the resolved
fraction in a number of narrow energy bands from 0.2 to 12 keV.
The authors found the resolved fraction to be 80 per cent below
2 keV, but that this decreased significantly at higher energies, falling

to only ∼50 per cent above ∼8 keV. The failure to account for XRB
in the harder bands, along with recent indications of steepening of
X-ray source number counts at low fluxes, suggest that there may
be an as yet undetected population of highly obscured sources, such
as the heavily absorbed AGN predicted in recent synthesis models
(e.g. Gilli, Salvati & Hasinger 2001; Franceschini, Braito & Fadda
2002; Gandhi & Fabian 2003; Ueda et al. 2003; Comastri 2004).
Although Chandra has low effective area at energies exceeding
7 keV, the Chandra Deep Fields (CDFs) probe to fainter flux lim-
its than the XMM–Newton Lockman Hole observation. We use the
CDFs to assess whether the contribution of the fainter sources found
by Chandra is able to resolve the discrepancy and account for the
missing background fraction. Using a similar photometric analysis,
we sum the flux from resolved CDF sources in a number of narrow
energy bands to determine the resolved fraction of the XRB. We
also present a re-analysis of the XMM–Newton Lockman Hole ob-
servation (Worsley et al. 2004), carried out in identical energy bands
for direct comparison with the CDFs. In both cases, we attempt to
quantify and correct for field-to-field variations and the missing flux,
which would arise from the very bright sources that are not sampled
in these deep, pencil-beam surveys.
2 S O U R C E D E T E C T I O N A N D P H OTO M E T RY
2.1 Chandra deep field observations
Chandra has performed the two deepest ever surveys of the X-
ray Universe: the 2-Ms CDF-N (Alexander et al. 2003) and the
1-Ms CDF-S (Giacconi et al. 2002). The CDF-N probes down to
∼2.5 × 10−17 and ∼1.4 × 10−16 erg cm−2s−1 in the 0.5–2 and 2–
8 keV bands, respectively. Although the CDF-S only reaches down
to equivalent limits [at signal-to-noise ratio (S/N ) = 3] of ∼5.2 ×
10−17 and ∼2.8 × 10−16 erg cm−2s−1, these are both well beyond
the 10−14 erg cm−2s−1 break in the log N – log S distribution (see
e.g. Hasinger et al. 1998; Campana et al. 2001).
For both the CDF-N and CDF-S, we use the source catalogues
and photometry from Alexander et al. (2003), who describe their
approach thoroughly; we include a brief summary here for com-
pleteness. The 2-Ms CDF-N main point-source catalogue contains
a total of 503 sources and covers a total solid angle of 447.8 arcmin2.
Conservative estimates place the number of falsely detected sources
to be as high as 20–30, but the true number is probably considerably
lower (see section 2.3 in Alexander et al. 2003). The CDF-S has 326
sources from a total field of 391.3 arcmin2.
The local background estimate for each source was determined
in an annulus surrounding the source-extraction region. The mean
number of background counts was computed assuming a Poisson
distribution, as n1/n0; where n1 is the number of pixels contain-
ing a single count and n0 is the number containing no counts. For
sources with less than 103 counts in the full 0.5–8 keV band, source-
extraction apertures containing 90–95 per cent of the encircled
energy fraction (EEF) were chosen (with the extracted counts cor-
rected up to 100 per cent). For sources brighter than 103 counts,
extraction apertures of twice this size were chosen; the EEF in these
cases is close to 100 per cent. The EEF corrections used to cor-
rect from aperture counts to total counts were calculated from the
Chandra point spread function (PSF) determined using the Chandra
X-ray Center MKPSF software (refer to Alexander et al. 2003).
For all sources with a sufficient number of counts, the ratio of
counts between the 2–8 keV and 0.5–2 keV bands was used to de-
termine an effective spectral index for a power-law model, allowing
for Galactic absorption of (1.3 ± 0.4) × 1020 and (8.8 ± 4.0) ×
1019 cm−2 for the CDF-N and CDF-S, respectively (Lockman 2003;
Stark et al. 1992). For sources with an insufficient number of counts,
the photon index is fixed at  = 1.4 (the approximate average for all
the sources and the slope of the XRB). The flux for each source was
calculated in a number of photometric bands, regardless of whether
or not the source is actually detected in each of the bands. In each
case, the counts-to-flux conversion is appropriate to the spectral in-
dex of the source. The photometric bands used were 0.5–1, 1–2,
2–4, 4–6 and 6–8 keV.
Prior to our stacking analysis (described in Section 3.1), we
applied the systematic flux correction determined by Bauer et al.
(2004) for both the CDFs (see section 3 and fig. 2 of their paper).
These take into account Eddington bias as well as some further
aperture/photometry effects that were not considered originally. The
correction is negligible except in the harder (>2 keV) bands, which
each see an increase in total resolved flux of ∼2–5 per cent.
2.2 XMM–Newton Lockman Hole observations
XMM–Newton, whilst unable to match the X-ray resolution and
ultimate sensitivity of Chandra, has the critical advantage of sensi-
tivity in the 8–12 keV regime. It was this capability, put into effect
with ∼700 ks of deep observations in the Lockman Hole (XMM-
Lockman Hole, XMM-LH), that prompted Worsley et al. (2004) to
investigate the resolved fraction of the XRB with energy.
The 17 different individual observations that comprise the XMM-
LH were combined and source detection carried out using sliding-
box detection followed by maximum-likelihood PSF fitting. Vi-
sual inspection of the source candidates was used to exclude
spurious detections. The analysis was restricted to the central
314.2-arcmin2 region of the field with the highest exposure time
and lowest background level.
In a similar approach to that taken in the CDFs, simple aperture
photometry was performed on the exposure-corrected images in a
number of narrow energy bands. A more detailed description of the
following is given by Worsley et al. (2004). For each source, the total
count rates were extracted in both a circular aperture and a surround-
ing annulus. These were then used to calculate the background-
corrected source count rate, taking into account corrections for the
EEF. These corrections were calculated by integrating an analytical
model of the XMM–Newton PSF given in XMM–Newton Science
Operations Centre calibration documents (refer to Worsley et al.
2004). Count-rate extraction apertures/annuli were chosen to the
maximize the signal-to-noise ratio.
Count-rate–to–flux conversion factors were computed assuming
a fixed spectral slope of  = 1.4 and Galactic absorption with a
column density of 5 × 1019 cm−2 (Lockman, Jahoda & McCammon
1986). This is not as rigorous as the approach taken in the CDFs
where counts-to-flux energy conversion factors (ECFs) appropriate
to the spectral slope of the source were used, but the larger count-rate
errors for the XMM–Newton sources prohibit this and the assumption
of a fixed  = 1.4 is more reliable. Furthermore, the dependence of
the ECFs on the spectral shape of a source is only weak because of
the use of narrow energy bands. The ECFs of all but the 0.2–0.5 keV
band vary by  5 per cent over the range  = 0.9–1.9 (the 0.2–
0.5 keV band has a ∼15 per cent variation). The resultant uncertainty
in the resolved total flux from the source population is small in
comparison with other errors.
In order to allow easy comparison with the Chandra data, the
XMM-LH analysis was repeated using the same energy bands as in
the CDFs with additional bands covering 0.2–0.5 and 8–12 keV. The
re-processing of the data took advantage of the latest releases of the

3 R E S U LT S
3.1 Resolving the X-ray background
The total resolved flux in each energy band was calculated by sum-
ming the measured flux for each source. Every source is included
regardless of whether or not it is detected in the band. This was
done for the CDF-N, CDF-S and each of the three XMM–Newton
instruments in the XMM-LH. Appropriate corrections for Galactic
absorption were made. These correction factors are: 15 per cent
in the XMM-LH 0.2–0.5 keV band; 2.6, 7.2 and 4.8 per cent in the
0.5–1 keV band for the XMM-LH, CDF-N and CDF-S, respectively;
and 1 per cent for all of the harder bands.
In order to calculate the resolved intensity, the flux from each
source must be divided by a solid angle on the sky. In the case of the
XMM-LH, the sensitivity is approximately constant over the region
considered here and we simply take the solid angle to be a constant
314.2 arcmin2. The CDFs, however, show a substantial increase in
sensitivity towards the centre of the fields. The total solid angles of
447.8 and 391.3 arcmin2 are only applicable to the brightest sources,
whereas fainter sources are only detectable over a fraction of the field
and the actual solid angles are smaller. Fig. 19 in Alexander et al.
(2003) shows the solid angle as a function of 0.5-8 keV source flux in
the CDF-N. We use this function (and its equivalent for the CDF-S)
to provide the appropriate solid angle when converting each source
flux to an intensity. We impose a minimum effective area of 10 per
cent of the total to avoid catastrophically magnifying the errors in
the fluxes from the faintest sources.
Fig. 1(a) shows the resolved XRB fraction obtained in each energy
band. The fractions are calculated using the most recent estimates
of the total extragalactic XRB spectrum. For the 1–8 keV band,
this is the power-law model of De Luca & Molendi (2004), with a
spectral slope of  = 1.41 and 1 keV normalization of 11.6 keV
cm−2s−1sr−1keV−1. Above 8 keV, the background spectrum starts
to turn over slightly and so here we use the analytical model of
Gruber et al. (1999), which takes the downturn into account, but

renormalized to the same 2–8 keV XRB flux as found by De Luca
& Molendi (2004). The spectrum of the purely extragalactic back-
ground is not well constrained below 1 keV because it is difficult to
separate from the bright, diffuse, Galactic component. There is evi-
dence to suggest that the spectrum of the background steepens below
∼1 keV; Roberts & Warwick (2001) have combined the results of
several X-ray shadowing measurements and report a background
intensity of 26.6 ± 4.8 keV cm−2 s−1 sr−1keV−1 at 0.25 keV. A
power-law fit between this value and the De Luca & Molendi (2004)
intensity at 1 keV gives a spectral slope of  ∼ 1.5–1.7, and we use
this to estimate the background levels in the 0.2–0.5 and 0.5–1 keV
bands.
The stacking of source fluxes reveals a decline in the resolved
XRB fraction as a function of energy. Below ∼2 keV, the data di-
verge somewhat, presumably as a result of field-to-field variations.
Such variations arise through the cosmic variance in the actual XRB
normalization in different regions of the sky, along with the statisti-
cal noise, which is a consequence of sampling a discrete population
of sources in a small solid angle. Fig. 1(b) shows the result of ex-
cluding sources with a 0.5–8 keV band flux >5 × 10−14 erg cm−2
s−1 from the sum. While only a small number of sources have been
removed (from 3–7 out of 156–503), the variation at the softest en-
ergies has been reduced considerably. This demonstrates that a large
amount of the variation <2 keV is the result of soft, bright sources.
The XMM-LH data now show a slight decline in the resolved frac-
tion whilst the CDFs show a slight rise, although both CDFs show
significant drops in the 6–8 keV band. This difference between the
XMM–Newton and Chandra fractions in the 4–6 keV band is the re-
sult of sensitivity: the CDFs probe down to fainter fluxes where the
typical source spectrum is harder than  = 1.4 (see e.g. Alexander
et al. 2003; Streblyanska et al. 2004). If the source lists are further
restricted to remove the faint sources seen only by Chandra, with a
minimum flux requirement of 10−16 erg cm−2 s−1, then the spectral
shapes of the sources are similar for both XMM-LH and CDF, see
Fig. 1(c). Of course, there will always remain differences between
data sets: Barcons, Mateos & Ceballos (2000) estimate the cosmic
variation in XRB normalization to be of order ∼10 per cent for fields
of 1 deg2.
3.2 Correcting for the bright-end population
The brightest sources in the catalogues have 0.5–8 keV fluxes up to
∼(1–3) × 10−13 erg cm−2 s−1. There is a non-negligible contribution
to the whole-sky background by sources brighter than this; in fact,
around 15–20 per cent of the total XRB is the result of bright, rare
sources that are not sampled in pencil-beam surveys. A bright-end
correction is necessary to recover this missing intensity.
In order to remove some of the bright-end variation, we truncate
the source lists above 5 × 10−14 erg cm−2 s−1(0.5–8 keV band).
This is the same truncation as used in Fig. 1(b) and corresponds to
removing sources that only occur with densities of ∼ a few in the
∼0.1-deg2 CDF and XMM-LH fields. With the bright-end sources
removed, the expected missing flux can be estimated by integrating
known log N–log S distributions. These are available in the broad
0.5–2 and 2–10 keV bands but not in the narrow bands used in this
work. In order to calculate the contribution in a narrow band, it is
necessary to assume the spectral shape of the sources. Here, we
assume a power-law spectrum but the typical spectral slope of such
a power-law can be a strong function of source flux.
A number of studies point to significant evolution of the spectral
shape with flux (Ueda et al. 1999; Alexander et al. 2003; Fiore
et al. 2003; Streblyanska et al. 2004), with sources brighter than
∼10−14 erg cm−2 s−1 having typical spectral slopes much softer
than the  = 1.4 of the total background. Shallow surveys (see
e.g. Ueda et al. 1999) find that the brightest sources, with X-ray
fluxes 10−13 erg cm−2 s−1, have spectral slopes of  ∼ 1.8–2.2.
Streblyanska et al. (2004) fitted a power-law spectrum to the stacked
spectra of sources of a 500-ks XMM–Newton observation in the
CDF-S. Fitting the hard band (1–8 keV) with a power law reveals
a strong correlation between spectral slope and flux, with  ∼ 1.8
for ∼10−13 erg cm−2 s−1 (2–10 keV flux) decreasing to  ∼ 1.5 at
∼10−14 erg cm−2 s−1 and  ∼ 1.2 at ∼10−15 erg cm−2 s−1. Alexander
et al. (2003) see sources with  ∼ 1 at fluxes 10−16 erg cm−2 s−1
in the CDF-N.
We haven taken a linear fit to the evolution of spectral index with
flux based on the relationship as observed by Streblyanska et al.
(2004), although we conservatively impose a maximum value of
 = 2. Such a model is only an approximation to the actual depen-
dence of spectral shape on flux. It does, however, follow the trends
observed by Streblyanska et al. (2004) in the CDF-S (using both
XMM–Newton and Chandra observations) and Ueda et al. (1999)
using the ASCA Medium-Sensitivity Survey and, whilst crude, it is
important to take into account the fact that the bright-end correction
is the result of sources that are significantly softer than those that
we have already stacked. Given our model, the bright-source con-
tribution in each of the 2–4, 4–6, 6–8 and 8–12 keV narrow bands
can then be calculated, using an appropriate spectral index at each
source flux, from the 2–10 keV flux contribution obtained by inte-
grating the Moretti et al. (2003) hard band log N–log S distribution
(the most complete published to date).
Correcting the soft bands (0.2–0.5, 0.5–1 and 1–2 keV) is more
complex, because the shape of the background is not well con-
strained. The source stacking approach of Streblyanska et al. (2004)
in the 0.4–8 keV range revealed a systematically softer spectrum
than that seen for 1–8 keV (an increase in  of ∼0.1). No stud-
ies cover the 0.5–2 keV range ideally required for the soft band
bright-end correction so we take the same linear fit to the evolu-
tion of spectral index as used in the hard band, but with an increase
in  by 0.1. We use the Moretti et al. (2003) 0.5–2 keV soft band
log N – log S distribution. There is now some evidence to suggest
that the Moretti et al. (2003) log N – log S slope is too steep at
the bright end compared with results from the RIXOS,1 RBS2 and
NEPS3 surveys (Mason et al. 2000; Schwope et al. 2000; Gioia
et al. 2003); thus, our bright-end correction in the soft band could
potentially be an underestimate.
Fig. 2 shows the bright-end corrected resolved background frac-
tions. The XMM-LH, CDF-S and CDF-N are all consistent with a
similar resolved fraction of ∼70–90 per cent up to ∼4 keV. The dif-
ferences are of order ∼10 per cent, which is not inconsistent with
what would be expected from cosmic variance between the fields
(see Barcons et al. 2000). XMM–Newton sees a drop in the resolved
fraction in the 4–6 keV band, whereas the CDFs are still consistent
with a high resolved fraction of ∼80–90 per cent. This difference
is a result of the faint, hard sources, which are not detected in the
XMM-LH; if these sources are removed from the Chandra data then
all three data sets show agreement in the 4–6 keV fraction. Most
importantly, the picture is different at high energies; XMM–Newton
and both CDFs only resolve ∼50–70 per cent of the background
in the 6–8 keV band, much less than the fraction at lower energies.
The 8–12 keV band, as probed by XMM–Newton, is only ∼40–
60 per cent resolved.

We find the total resolved fluxes in the 0.5–2 and 2–8 keV bands
to be (6.9 ± 0.2) × 10−12 and (1.5 ± 0.1) × 10−11 erg cm−2 s−1
for the CDF-N. These compare well to the (6.7 ± 0.3) × 10−12 and

We find the total 0.5–2 and 2–8 keV resolved fractions are ∼85
and ∼80 per cent for the CDF-N (using the total XRB spectrum we
describe in Section 3.1). Such high fractions are often used to claim
that the XRB is almost completely resolved into discrete sources
even in the broad 2–10 keV band. Our results suggest that stating a
resolved fraction in this manner is misleading, because it is the high
resolved fractions in the 2–6 keV range that are dominating the total,
whilst the resolved fraction beyond 6 keV is significantly lower.
4 D I S C U S S I O N
Three independent observations now point to a significant reduction
in the resolved fraction of the XRB at the hardest energies. XMM–

cent confidence contours are shown. The best-fitting point is indicated at z
∼ 0.8 and N H ∼ 4.5 × 1023 cm−2. The grey contours indicate the maxi-

Newton starts to see a downturn above ∼4 keV, whilst Chandra is
sensitive to the fainter, harder sources, which fill in some of the
missing fraction and push the downturn to energies 6 keV. The
missing fraction has the spectral signature of highly obscured AGN
and could be evidence of the large population of heavily absorbed
objects that are thought to account for the 30 keV peak of XRB
intensity (see e.g. Maiolino et al. 1998, 2003).
To quantify the possible nature of an undetected population, we
modelled the spectral shape of the unresolved background as a func-
tion of redshift and intrinsic absorption column density. A grid of
spectra was built in the range z = 0.1–3 and N H = 1022–1025 cm−2.
XSPEC V11.3.1 was used to generate the spectra using a PEXRAV model
(Magdziarz & Zdziarski 1995), with a  = 2 power law and an
R = 1 reflection component (see e.g. Malizia et al. 2003), multiplied
by ZWABS (Morrison & McCammon 1983) photoelectric absorption
at the source redshift.
We computed the goodness-of-fit between each model spectrum
and the residual XRB spectrum (i.e. the difference between the re-
solved and total backgrounds). Fig. 3 shows the confidence contours
in the redshift and absorption column density required to account for
the shape of the missing AGN population for the XMM-LH. This is
a rather simplistic approximation to the spectra of highly obscured
sources; specifically, we neglect the effects of iron K emission and
scattered-flux components, as well as assuming that the missing
sources occur at a fixed redshift and with a fixed absorption col-
umn density. Nevertheless, some generalized conclusions about the
nature of the unresolved population can be drawn.
The XMM-LH, CDF-N and CDF-S all show similar contour dia-
grams for the characteristics of the missing source population. The
XMM-LH data, which extends to the 8–12 keV band, shows the most
constrained set of contours although the degeneracy between low
z/low NH and high z/high NH is clear. The best-fitting point is at
z ∼ 0.8 and N H ∼ 4.5 × 1023 cm−2. For the CDF-N and CDF-S, the
lack of data above 8 keV results in much more relaxed contours al-
though there is again some preference for sources at z ∼ 0.5–1.5 with
N H ∼ 1023–1024 cm−2. Fig. 4 shows the total and resolved levels of
the XRB in ν I ν as well as the intensity that would be contributed
by the best-fitting model of an obscured population.

Figure 4. The upper curve shows the total extragalactic XRB (as described
in Section 3.1) in ν I ν . The intensity resolved into sources in the CDF-N,
CDF-S and XMM-LH are shown as black crosses, grey crosses and black

1023 cm−2. Sharp features (such as that due to iron at 4 keV), is a consequence
of our assumption that the missing population is composed entirely of AGN
with this spectrum. In reality the missing population will be mixture of
sources at different redshifts and with different levels of absorption; any
sharp features will be smeared out.
We conclude that whilst the data are unable to constrain tightly
the spectral shape of the missing XRB sources, the most plausible
population would seem to be of objects at redshifts of ∼0.5–1.5, with
unabsorbed luminosities of 5 × 1043 erg s−1, but heavily obscured
by column densities of ∼1023–1024 cm−2. The CDFs probe deeper
than the XMM-LH but still fail to detect the missing sources in the
2–4 keV band, or our stacking analysis would have revealed the
higher energy emission. Any soft starburst or scattered emission in
these objects must be small and this may suggest a high covering
fraction for the absorption.
In order to provide the missing fraction of the hard XRB, these
sources must have a density on the sky of2800 deg−2. This would
correspond to a lower limit of around 350 undetected AGN in the
CDF-N. There must therefore be >3 times more undetected, ob-
scured sources than detected, unobscured ones, in the 4–8 keV band.
This requires that the sources in the new population have a high cov-
ering fraction of obscuring matter.
From the absorption-corrected flux, we can estimate the black
hole mass density of this obscured population to be (6–9 × 104)
−1−1κ−1 M Mpc−3; where −1 is the accretion efficiency in units
of 0.1 and κ−1 is a bolometric correction in units of 0.1. We have used
a similar calculation to Fabian & Iwasawa (1999) although note that
the bolometric correction is ∼10–15 for our lower luminosity ob-
jects (Fabian 2004). The missing population thus accounts for ∼10–
20 per cent of the local black hole mass density of 4–5 × 105 M
Mpc−3 (see e.g. Shankar et al. 2004), the rest of which is the re-
sult of bright AGN and, in particular, quasars, where the bolometric
correction is ∼30 or more and where a typical redshift of z ∼ 2 is
more appropriate (refer to Fabian & Iwasawa 1999 and references
therein).
The steepness of the 5–10 keV source number counts, with no
evidence for a break to a flatter slope at the faint end, also indicates
that there remains a substantial number of objects that have yet
to be found in this band (Hasinger et al. 2001; Baldi et al. 2002;
Rosati et al. 2002). Recent optical and infrared data from the HST
and Spitzer telescopes, acquired as part of the Great Observatories
Origins Deep Survey (GOODS) project, are also providing evidence
for large numbers of obscured AGN at z > 1 (e.g. Treister et al.
2004). Deep, multiwavelength efforts such as GOODS may well
be the best way to identify the missing population; confirmation
of Compton-thick objects will ultimately require X-ray missions
with high sensitivities beyond 10 keV, such as the next generation
of focusing hard X-ray telescopes.
5 C O N C L U S I O N S
(i) Whilst the XRB is ∼85 and ∼80 per cent resolved in the broad
0.5–2 and 2–10 keV bands respectively (depending on XRB normal-
ization), it is only ∼60 per cent resolved above ∼6 keV and ∼50
per cent resolved above ∼8 keV. This decrease in resolved fraction
is seen in both the CDFs and the XMM-LH.
(ii) The decrease in resolved fraction as seen in XMM-LH occurs
at energies 4 keV, whilst in the CDFs the drop occurs at 6 keV.
This difference is the result of faint, hard sources, which are de-
tected in CDFs but not the XMM-LH. All three surveys are unable
to account for almost half of the XRB above ∼6 keV.
(iii) The missing fraction has a spectral shape that is consistent
with that which would be expected from a population of faint, heav-
ily obscured AGN located at a redshift of ∼0.5–1.5 and with intrinsic
absorption columns of ∼1023–1024 cm−2.
(iv) The deep CDF data show that any such obscured population
is not detected in the 2–4 keV band, or our stacking analysis would
have revealed the higher energy emission; consequently, any soft
scattered or starburst emission from these objects must be small.
